nodes.text: The error resilience of DNN systems depends on data types, numeric value ranges, bit positions, data reuse patterns, and layer types, and targeted software and hardware protections can substantially reduce Silent Data Corruption (SDC) and restore reliability to meet safety standards

We modified an open-source DNN simulator (Tiny-CNN) to model a canonical DNN accelerator and injected random single-bit transient faults across four neural networks (ConvNet, AlexNet, CaffeNet, NiN) to characterize error propagation

Fault model and parameter sweep: transient single-event upsets in datapath latches and buffer storage were injected; experiments evaluated multiple data types (DOUBLE, FLOAT, FLOAT16, 32b_rb26, 32b_rb10, 16b_rb10), bit positions, layer positions, and data-reuse buffer contexts including an Eyeriss case study

Large-scale fault injection (3,000 faults per latch per location, 95% CIs) across network topologies shows SDC probabilities vary widely with network depth and topology, data type, bit position, layer type/position and data reuse

Bit-level sensitivity evidence: for floating point, high-order exponent bits (not mantissa or sign) are most likely to cause SDCs; for fixed point, high-order integer bits are most vulnerable and vulnerability depends on binary-point placement (dynamic range)

Value-deviation evidence: faults that produce large magnitude deviations in activation values are much more likely to cause SDCs; normalization layers (e.g., LRN) reduce impact by averaging faulty values with neighbors and thereby mask faults

Network and layer structure results: shallower networks without normalization (ConvNet) exhibit much higher SDC probabilities; deeper networks and layers with normalization or pooling/ReLU mask a large fraction of faults, but fully-connected layers tend to have higher impact on final rankings

Buffer (Eyeriss) case study evidence: faults in buffers (global buffer, filter SRAM) produce substantially higher SDC probabilities and projected FIT rates than datapath latches due to larger storage size and reuse (same faulty value read multiple times)

FIT rate result: Calculated datapath and buffer FIT rates show that without protection a DNN accelerator (example Eyeriss projections) can exceed ISO 26262/SoC FIT budgets by orders of magnitude; buffers can dominate the accelerator FIT budget

Claim and design implication: selecting data types that provide just-enough dynamic range and precision (reducing redundant dynamic range) can reduce SDC susceptibility and lower FIT rates by orders of magnitude

Symptom-based Detector (SED) method: learn layer-wise activation value ranges offline with a 10% safety cushion, then asynchronously check global buffer activation values at layer boundaries at runtime to detect anomalous out-of-range activations

SED evaluation evidence: across selected networks and data types (DOUBLE, FLOAT, FLOAT16, 32b_rb10) SED yields average precision ~90.2% and recall ~92.5%, and can reduce projected FIT of Eyeriss significantly (example: FLOAT FIT reduced from 8.55 to 0.35)

Selective Latch Hardening (SLH) method: prioritize hardening of the most SDC-sensitive latches (bits) using a mix of hardened latch designs (strike suppression, redundant node, TMR) guided by sensitivity models to minimize area while maximizing FIT reduction

SLH evaluation evidence: exploiting asymmetric bit sensitivity and combining hardened-latch types can reduce datapath latch FIT by about 100x while incurring roughly 20â€“25% latch area overhead in evaluated cases (e.g., AlexNet on Eyeriss with FLOAT16 or 16b_rb10)

Conclusion: Applying the proposed combination of defenses (data-type selection, SED, selective latch hardening) can substantially lower SDC rates and FIT projections and can restore DNN accelerator reliability to meet safety standards with acceptable overheads
